<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 636, 145]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 211, 425, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 211, 905, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 178, 293]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|> 9702/33 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 359, 317]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|> February/March 2024 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 400]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 222, 434]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 280, 450]]<|/det|> Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 808, 466]]<|/det|> Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|> Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|> Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 480, 512]]<|/det|> Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 359, 527]]<|/det|> Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 798, 544]]<|/det|> You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 544, 892, 575]]<|/det|> You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 320, 590]]<|/det|> You may use a calculator. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 590, 578, 605]]<|/det|> You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 212, 649]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 651, 384, 666]]<|/det|> The total mark for this paper is 40. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 667, 729, 682]]<|/det|> The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[680, 732, 905, 860]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 740, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 99, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 680, 121]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the properties of a pendulum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 180, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 133, 715, 152]]<|/det|>
• Assemble the apparatus as shown in Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 164, 918, 183]]<|/det|>
• Push the nail through the central hole in the pendulum and then into the plastic tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 196, 710, 214]]<|/det|>
• Secure the tube and nail in the boss, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[247, 223, 747, 330]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 346, 532, 364]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 377, 655, 396]]<|/det|>
• Ensure that the pendulum swings freely on the nail.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 403, 799, 765]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 777, 534, 795]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Attach two \(50\mathrm{g}\) slotted masses to the pendulum using the bolts and nuts. Use two holes which are the same distance \(x\) from the nail, as shown in Fig. 1.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 112, 715, 475]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 488, 534, 505]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 518, 220, 536]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 518, 697, 536]]<|/det|>
The distance from the centre of each bolt to the nail is \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 549, 220, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 549, 423, 567]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 580, 917, 598]]<|/det|>
<form>\(x =\) .......................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 580, 920, 598]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 612, 181, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 612, 866, 630]]<|/det|>
Push the bottom of the pendulum a short distance to one side and then release it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 643, 729, 661]]<|/det|>
Take measurements to determine the period \(T\) of the oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 791, 920, 810]]<|/det|>
<form>T = ...............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 792, 920, 810]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 541, 89]]<|/det|>
Vary \(x\) by using different holes and measure \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 579, 120]]<|/det|>
Repeat until you have six sets of values of \(\mathbf{x}\) and \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 702, 152]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\sqrt{x^3}\) in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 520, 920, 539]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 551, 143, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 551, 175, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 551, 665, 570]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(T\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\sqrt{x^3}\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 551, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 583, 180, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 583, 457, 602]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 583, 920, 602]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 613, 180, 632]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 613, 608, 632]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 829, 917, 848]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 861, 917, 880]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 740, 91]]<|/det|>
You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 96, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 751, 121]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the frictional forces on a wooden strip.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 180, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 133, 831, 151]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with two wooden strips. Select the **thicker** strip.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 164, 500, 183]]<|/det|>
Measure and record its length \(L\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 195, 920, 213]]<|/det|>
<form>L = ....................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 225, 220, 244]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 225, 920, 260]]<|/det|>
Attach the slotted mass to one of the wider faces of the strip approximately \(10 \text{cm}\) from one end using a small piece of adhesive putty, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 268, 781, 359]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 368, 532, 386]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 400, 215, 418]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 400, 920, 434]]<|/det|>
The distance from the centre of the slotted mass to the nearest end of the strip is \(d_{\mathrm{A}}\), as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 446, 433, 465]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(d_{\mathrm{A}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 476, 920, 495]]<|/det|>
<form>d<sub>A</sub> = ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 494, 920, 512]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 523, 181, 542]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 523, 920, 556]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with a smooth board. Support the board vertically on the bench using the stand, boss and clamp, as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 562, 876, 920]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 930, 534, 947]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 947, 549, 959]]<|/det|>
9702/33/F/M/24

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[823, 945, 920, 961]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Turn over

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 215, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
Lean the strip against the smooth board with the slotted mass nearer the lower end, as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 119, 215, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 117, 920, 167]]<|/det|>
Move the bottom of the strip away from the smooth board until the strip starts to slip. Gradually push the bottom of the strip back towards the board until it just stays in position by itself.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 180, 213, 198]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 180, 811, 199]]<|/det|>
The angle between the strip and the bench is \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\), as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 212, 433, 229]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 272, 895, 291]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{A}} =\) ....................................................° [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 303, 180, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 303, 655, 322]]<|/det|>
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 319, 359, 337]]<|/det|>
Show your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 469, 920, 488]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = ....................................................% [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 500, 181, 518]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 500, 781, 518]]<|/det|>
The mass of the thicker strip is \(M.\) The value of \(M\) is written on the strip.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 532, 322, 549]]<|/det|>
<form>• Record \(M.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 562, 920, 580]]<|/det|>
<form>M = ............................................................ g

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 593, 390, 611]]<|/det|>
<form>• Calculate \(F_{\mathrm{A}}\) using

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 628, 576, 685]]<|/det|>
\[F_{\mathrm{A}} = \frac{M}{2} +\frac{Sd_{\mathrm{A}}}{L}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 701, 376, 720]]<|/det|>
where S is 100 g.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 865, 920, 883]]<|/det|>
<form>\(F_{\mathrm{A}} =\) ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 73, 181, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(v)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Invert the thicker strip and lean it against the smooth board so that the slotted mass is nearer the upper end as shown in Fig. 2.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 112, 828, 420]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 427, 534, 445]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 456, 210, 473]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 456, 910, 475]]<|/det|>
The distance from the centre of the slotted mass to the lower end of the strip is \(d_{\mathrm{B}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 484, 432, 503]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(d_{\mathrm{B}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 513, 920, 532]]<|/det|>
<form>\(d_{\mathrm{B}} =\) .................................................... cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 545, 210, 562]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 545, 920, 594]]<|/det|>
Move the bottom of the strip away from the smooth board until the strip starts to slip. Gradually push the bottom of the strip back towards the board until it just stays in position by itself.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 607, 210, 625]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 607, 811, 626]]<|/det|>
The angle between the strip and the bench is \(\theta_{\mathrm{B}}\), as shown in Fig. 2.3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 638, 432, 656]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(\theta_{\mathrm{B}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 736, 920, 754]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{B}} =\) ...........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 768, 213, 785]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 768, 395, 785]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(F_{\mathrm{B}}\), using

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 789, 586, 845]]<|/det|>
\[F_{\mathrm{B}} = \frac{M}{2} +\frac{Sd_{B}}{L} .\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 912, 920, 931]]<|/det|>
<form>\(F_{\mathrm{B}} =\) ...........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 928, 920, 945]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 628, 92]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the relationship between \(F_{\mathrm{A}}\) and \(F_{\mathrm{B}}\) is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[468, 95, 531, 128]]<|/det|>
\[k = \frac{F_{\mathrm{A}}}{F_{\mathrm{B}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 133, 339, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 164, 507, 183]]<|/det|>
Using your data, calculate two values of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 348, 917, 368]]<|/det|>
<form>first value of \(k =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 380, 920, 399]]<|/det|>
<form>second value of \(k =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 395, 920, 414]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 425, 146, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 425, 751, 444]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the percentage uncertainty in the values of \(k\) is \(15\%\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 456, 826, 476]]<|/det|>
Using this uncertainty, explain whether your results support the relationship in **(c)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 657, 920, 676]]<|/det|>
